I remember my first time I felt like I had found queer community: it was the summer before my senior year of high school, and I went to New York to study art at Parsons. The Sunday that I arrived in NYC, June 29 2003, was coincidentally the same day as New York City pride. The first person I met, Joe, and I decided to walk over to 5th Avenue and watch as the parade came down the street. More than anything, that summer served as an intensive in giving me understanding, language, and a sense of belonging in my own identity. I learned about and fell in love with the work of Catherine Opie, I spent afternoons at the piers with friends, I went to see Rent on Broadway with my friend Ojay, and knew that I was just beginning to figure out how expansive queer culture, and love, and relationships, and community can all be. I was enormously privileged to have that experience at 17 years old, and I know first hand how powerful and transformative it can be to have a supportive network of peers and mentors as we navigate our individual identities. In the spirit of that discovery, I'm proud to work with @fossil in support of #HMIxFossil #MakeTimeForGood. This pride month, Fossil is supporting the Hetrick Martin Institute with 100% of proceeds on the sale of their Live in Color watch going to HMI - the largest organization supporting LGBTQ youth and their families. As we celebrate 50 years since Stonewall, and 40 years since HMI opened it's doors, I want to aim the spotlight on the important organizations doing this work not just during Pride month, but all year long üåà‚ù§

Okay, so... I‚Äôve been getting a LOT of questions lately talking about what many have affectionately referred to as ‚Äúthe girls‚Äù or üçí or üçàüçà ‚Äî so, let‚Äôs talk about it! They appeared basically over night when I was in the 5th grade and I genuinely never had a ‚Äútraining bra phase‚Äù because I went from pre-pubescent and flat chested to a D cup before I could even really understand what these body changes meant. I now wear a 36H and while I like my body on most days, I‚Äôve also thought about breast reduction since I was a teenager, and still wonder how it might change my life. As for bras - I have and love SO MANY and am so grateful there are more beautiful options now than there ever have been in my lifetime. And finally, going braless (like I am here) is very, very new to me - and to be honest, I kind of love it, even though it‚Äôs also a bit intimidating and I feel like I‚Äôm breaking a LOT of rules, (and maybe those rules are kind of oppressive and rooted in respectability politics, anyways). Lots of tangents, here, but I get so many DMs about bras and cleavage and what to wear with XYZ that I figure, why not talk about it all in one place? Anyways, if you need bra recs, or tips on how to ditch them, or are struggling with boob sweat or something, leave a comment below and I‚Äôll do my best to share my not-so-secrets with you, cause boobs are great (if you want them!) üì∏ @taylorkrausecreative

In subtle and not-so-subtle ways, I wear my pride and identity on my sleeve every day; learning what "femme" identity was and the many ways that it can look, and that my femininity can be intentional and subversive, has liberated me to be my truest self in ways I never imagined. I'm so grateful to just... be ME, and have space to celebrate that -- not just during pride month, but all year round. I'm excited to partner with @fossil in support of their limited edition Live in Color watch, with 100% of proceeds going to @hetrickmartin, the largest LGBTQ youth organization in the country. #HMIxFossil #MakeTimeForGood #ad

I‚Äôve had a hard time thinking about anything else these last few days. Access to reproductive healthcare, choice, and the right to abortion is a PUBLIC HEALTH issue that disproportionately affects POC, low income communities, and the most marginalized among us. Over night, Missouri joined 5 other states that passed supposed ‚Äúheartbeat‚Äù bills - restricting access to reproductive healthcare at a timeframe before most people are even aware they may be pregnant. It‚Äôs so important to understand that this is not about ‚Äúsaving life‚Äù and never has been: it‚Äôs about control. If it was truly about saving life, we‚Äôd be investing resources into sex education, access to contraception, healthcare, childcare, welfare programs, parental leave (all of which we SHOULD be investing in, btw)‚Äî but we all know that, right? I know I live in a bubble - one that sometimes feels safe and separate from what‚Äôs happening ‚Äúover there,‚Äù but this feels scary and I feel it‚Äôs my responsibility to speak now, stay vigilant, and use the platform I have to encourage awareness around this issue. If you have the means, please consider donating to @aclu_nationwide, @yellowfund, @prochoiceamerica or one of the many local funds supporting access to safe reproductive healthcare near you. I also recommend following @ihartericka @pieraluisa @sarahsophief who have much smarter things to say than I do about this. (Image via @refinery29)

‚ÄúFLAWS‚Äù ARE SOCIALLY CONSTRUCTED. I‚Äôve been thinking about this question all day. Can we talk about this?? ETA: I assume good intent here and that the use of ‚Äúyou‚Äù is reflexive ‚Äî so don‚Äôt worry about me being offended bc I‚Äôm not. But I DO want to talk about and explore the idea of flaws and what we deem to be a flaw or perceive as flaws within ourselves or others. The idea is designed to MAKE US feel small, less than, less powerful than we are. I think it‚Äôs important to examine who is deciding certain things are flaws and WHY. So. Let‚Äôs talk about it. What are the things you‚Äôve been made to feel are flaws? Are they?

YOU‚ÄôRE A WORK IN PROGRESS. KEEP EVOLVING. ‚Äî I‚Äôve put together 33 things I‚Äôve learned in 33 years and consciously or not this was #33. You can read my other 32 in the link in my bio. ‚ú® PS: it‚Äôs definitely not meant as advice ‚Äî every person‚Äôs path, healing, choices, etc are their own; it‚Äôs just a collection of things I‚Äôve picked up over the years and wish I picked up sooner.

Boss talk ahead: One of the shadow sides of business is that entrepreneurship can feel like a tremendously isolating experience. As much of a blessing and a privilege as it is to be among the ‚Äúfirsts‚Äù in a field, it can also feel totally overwhelming to hear ‚Äúno‚Äù over and over and stay motivated to keep pushing forward. I feel lucky to have an incredible business partner (seriously, some days I think if it weren‚Äôt for having each other, we would have quit before we started) and a growing community of founders and entrepreneurs around me, but I still definitely have days where I go through a series of existential crises  and question everything. Turns out, the questioning is actually part of an entrepreneurs growth process, in and of itself, and that it‚Äôs FAR from an isolated experience. @mailchimp‚Äôs new podcast Going Through It features stories from people like Samin Nosrat, Hillary Clinton, and Soledad O‚ÄôBrien on a pivotal breakthrough moment in their lives. The first episode I listened to featured my friend and fat, queer, body-positive yogi @mynameisjessamyn, and it actually brought me to tears listening to her words echoing my own experiences. I‚Äôm starting this work week with a piece of wisdom care of Samin: ‚ÄúSay yes to no -- if you say yes to everything, then you can‚Äôt focus on anything.‚Äù AMEN. üì∏ @lydiahudgensphoto #MailchimpxRefinery29 #ad

It's always exciting to me whenever a brand joins the conversation around size inclusivity, and the @anthropologie launch was one I was long anticipating. I love the attention to detail, that the same pieces are available in straight sizes and many in petites as well, and how beautiful the fabrics are. I love that as this conversation evolves, more and more options are becoming available to people so that they can actually define their style on their own terms; it might seem like a small thing, but when you haven't had access to the kind of style or fashion that makes you feel like your authentic self - it's a really big deal. TGIF, amirite? Lots of new faces around here - so allow me to (re)introduce myself, and hopefully I can get to learn a little bit about some of you, too. My name is Nicolette (sometimes Nic, rarely Nikki, NEVER Nicole). I‚Äôm a Los Angeles native and moved to NYC in 2004, and for the last few years have split the majority of my life between those two cities. I‚Äôm a Taurus, Leo rising, Libra moon - and am celebrating my 33rd birthday very soon. I‚Äôm very, very gay and for some reason that still surprises people.  I love color (even though I wear black on most days), pugs, and would choose tacos or sushi over almost any other foods. I think pink is a neutral. I started my career as a brand strategist and designer, and started blogging around that same time as a hobby - which eventually, somehow, lead to working in fashion media - including being a contributing editor and columnist at Marie Claire for 5 years. I co-founded @premme.us with my bff and biz partner @gabifresh, where we make some bad ass clothes for size 12+ babes. I love to laugh, and try to learn something new every day. Ok, that was a lot ‚Äî YOUR TURN.

What does SELF LOVE mean to you? For me, it‚Äôs a journey, an exercise in patience, a practice in gratitude and emphasizing the things I truly love and appreciate about myself - my vulnerability, my kindness, my curiosity, my legs, my strength, my smile, my ambition, my loud and heartfelt laugh. It‚Äôs an understanding that there will be good days and there will be bad days, and that it‚Äôs okay to have bad days. Learning to love myself meant unlearning all the things that told me not to, and unlocking something inside me that only I could find. @katespadeny #loveinspades #ad üì∏ @ju_wels

In 2019 we are shedding the remnants of the internalized fatphobia we‚Äôve been carrying, (or at least I am). I‚Äôve had this coat for at least two years (maybe 3? @gabifresh modeled it in their look book and I fell I love with it instantly); it‚Äôs been taking up space in my closet (which is truly precious real estate) and I have... probably never worn it outside. Every now and then I have to check in with myself on the ways I try to minimize myself and my body, so in 2019 I am really consciously working on NOT DOING THAT. We deserve to exist in the world, command attention and visibility, to wear a big flamboyant fuzzy coat that exaggerates rather than ‚Äúflatters,‚Äù and have fun - period.
Happy 2019 from the future!!!!

"Self-care" isn't all bath bombs and face masks. Trust me, I love a good bath and a solid moisturizing mask, but for me, self-care has become more about spreadsheets (hello, adulthood) and work-outs. Whether it's taking a walk around the neighborhood mid-day during work hours, or getting myself up before the crack of dawn to jump on a 6AM spin session, I've learned the importance of breaking a sweat in order to realign my body and mind. It is such a necessary part of my mental health routine! While I'm not really one for "resolutions," I do love goals - so I've been challenging myself to get active and move more throughout the day. My @fossil sport smartwatch allows me to set custom goals, and track them, that are actually realistic and beneficial for me - all while tracking my heart rate and allowing me to set little reminders like drinking more water throughout the day, too. What does self-care mean to you? #ad #fossilstyle

The theme for 2018 for me has been HEALING. Big time. It was important for me to heal (for me, how other people navigate their lives is entirely their choice) before opening up about my vulnerabilities and pain points. 2017 was one of the best years of my life professionally, but absolutely my hardest, most challenging year on a personal level - an imbalance that in and of itself felt like a confrontational rollercoaster. There were so many enormous shifts - I went through a separation, decided to sell and move out of the home we shared in LA, my entire career life shifted rapidly, I developed new autoimmune issues, and my whole world very quickly felt like it was upside down. I wasn‚Äôt ready to answer questions like ‚Äúwhat happened?‚Äù ‚Äî as if there‚Äôs a simple answer, or even owed that to anyone but myself. Some things are best kept private, but I will say: we‚Äôre still close and have a lot of love for each other. Then 2018 came knocking and I knew it was time to focus on rebuilding, all wabi-sabi and full of imperfections and transience and change. And I feel good, now. Really good. I‚Äôm more confident, stronger, more patient, trusting myself and my intuition more. I committed myself back to therapy, said ‚Äúno‚Äù to more things to say ‚Äúyes‚Äù to myself, spent more time with my family, learned how to ask for help and support and patience, and got really fucking good at crying it out and processing all my feelings. So many of my friends have been facing similar changes, and that sense of community and knowing I‚Äôm not alone has made all the difference - and maybe it will help for one of you to know you‚Äôre not alone, either. Not everything has to be forever to have still been a really good time. And hey, everyone gets hyper reflective this time of year, right?! Nothing but gratitude for this process üñ§

You know how I (and everyone, basically) always say ‚Äúbody positivity is a journey‚Äù? I‚Äôve been echoing that back to myself on repeat recently. A combination of stress, a major shift in my routine, and the fact that I‚Äôve PROBABLY replaced all the water I usually drink with coffee, have made me not really feel like myself these past couple of months, and even actively feel sort of... not great. It‚Äôs really bizarre to not recognize yourself when part of your job is to put yourself out there ‚Äî and then feel so stifled that you accidentally stop doing it entirely. I was talking about this yesterday with a friend and had to really remind myself that the things we see or criticize or nit pick in ourselves are not things other people would ever even notice.
